From: David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...>
Subject: Re: [cantera] bulk phase concentration and interface reactions
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=TSIPne32Emv-TMPnWfvnQSKsz7-4UETNouceJ5hKWCCI
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

Steven,

Three-phase boundary reactions!  You are now deep into uncharted 
Cantera territory...  Of course, Cantera can do this, and I use it for 
this in SOFC simulations. But I haven't written anything up about how 
to do it. It sounds like you're figuring it out though.

A few points:

1.  Use "incompressible_solid" instead of "stoichiometric_solid" if you 
want to have multiple bulk species. If you specify a stoichiometric 
solid, then the activity is always 1.0 in computing reaction rates, 
unlike an "incompressible_solid", where the activity is the mole 
fraction.

But note also that in an electrolyte like YSZ, the vacancy 
concentration is very nearly constant, since it must compensate the 
excess negative charge due to the immobile Y atoms on the Zr sites (+3 
instead of +4 valence).  If the vacancy concentration were to deviate 
more than a very small amount from 0.5 * (Y concentration) then there 
would be a net space charge and big internal electric fields, which 
would cause the vacancies to move until they just compensate the Y 
charge.  So as a result, the vacancy concentration is essentially fixed 
by the Y doping level, and is not really variable.

2.  To simulate a metal electrode, use entry type "metal" in the cti 
file. The only species needed is an electron, since this is the only 
bulk metal species that participates in the chemistry.  As with 
"stoichiometric_solid", "metal" assigns unit activity to the electron 
species, so the reaction rate does not depend on any "concentration" of 
electrons.

For example, here's my definition of "nickel":

metal(name = "nickel",
       elements = "E",
       species = "e_Ni",
       density = (8.908, 'kg/m3'),
       initial_state = state( temperature =tt, mole_fractions = 
'e_Ni:1.0'))

species( name = "e_Ni",   atoms = "E:1",
         thermo = const_cp(h0 = (0.0, 'kcal/mol')))


3.  You can set each phase to a different potential, and reactions that 
transfer net charge across an interface will have their activation 
energies modified by the potential difference. By default the symmetry 
parameter beta = 0.5, but other values can be specified.

As it turns out, I am working on writing up some examples of 
electrochemical calculations with Cantera.  I'll give you a copy of 
what I write in a couple of weeks.

Dave


On Jun 6, 2005, at 12:48 PM, DeCal_12 wrote:

> Hello all,
>
> I am trying to incorporate three-phase-boundary reactions into a
> numerical simulation of a solid oxide fuel cell.  I am using cantera
> primarily for kinetics and thermo calculations.
>
> I have a couple questions about handling bulk phases.  So far I've
> defined an interface with a gas phase, several adsorbed surface
> species, and two bulk phases (one for oxide ions in the electrolyte,
> and one for oxide vacancies in the electrolyte).  My questions are:
>
> -is there any way to combine the two bulk phases into one phase?
> Creating a stoichiometric solid seems to only allow one species.
>
> -for reactions involving the oxide ions or vacancies in the
> electrolyte, the rates should obviously depend on the concentrations
> of said species.  How can this concentration be changed?  I've tried
> changing the phase density, both in the cti file and
> through 'setDensity' in the Matlab interface, but the results of the
> call to 'netprodrates(interface)' remain unchanged.
>
> Can anyone please help?
>
>
> Thanks,
> Steven DeCaluwe
